awd_titl_txt: CAREER: End-User Programming of General-Purpose Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots that can assist humans in everyday tasks have the potential to improve people's quality of life and bring independence to persons with disabilities.  A key challenge in realizing such robots is programming them to meet the unique and changing needs of users and to robustly function in their unique environments.  Most research in robotics targets this challenge by attempting to develop universal or adaptive robotic capabilities.  This approach has had limited success because it is extremely difficult to anticipate all possible scenarios and use-cases for general-purpose robots.  Instead, this research aims to develop robots that can be programmed in-context and by end-users after they are deployed.  The PI's approach is to apply and extend methods from the broad research area of end-user programming, which has previously been limited to personal computers, smart phones, and Web applications, to programming robots.  Project outcomes will have long-term societal and economic impacts, particularly on individuals with varying levels of motor impairments.  To further broaden the impacts of this research, the project will involve several outreach and educational activities focused on broadening participation of women and individuals with disabilities in computer science education, research, and careers.  These activities will directly integrate tools developed in the project, within three educational outreach modules for K-12 students and one undergraduate course.  Outreach modules will target three venues with different time scales; a week-long summer camp for students with disabilities organized by the UW DO-IT center, a three-hour exercise for a "Girls who Code" field trip, and one-hour exercise for an "Hour of Code" event.  The Robotics Capstone course developed by the PI will be updated to integrate tools developed in this project and to focus on projects within assistive robotics with the involvement of an actual customer.  All tools will be implemented on a state-of-the-art mobile manipulator robot, PR2, and will be released as open-source projects.  A truly unique aspect of this research is that developed tools will be deployed on two privately-owned in-home PR2 robots, leading to first insights from real-world evaluations.

To achieve her goal the PI will address challenges related to distinct characteristics of robots including situatedness, ability to influence the environment, mobility, distributed concurrent processing, and overall complexity.  This research will produce a suite of new methods and tools within three programming paradigms: (i) "situated programming" which involves programming through direct interactions with the robot and its environment, (ii) "simplified programming" which involves actual programming but with highly simplified languages, and (iii) "abstracted programming" which involves manipulating abstractions of program entities for which programs are synthesized automatically.  All methods will be instantiated as tools for programming robots at multiple levels, including programming of new knowledge, skills, tasks, and rules.  The main objectives of the projects are to make these tools (i) expressive enough to capture useful real-world tasks, (ii) usable by people with no technical background, and (iii) accessible to people with diverse abilities.  The first objective will be evaluated through systematic experiments with a comprehensive user-centered benchmark for domestic assistive robots, including programming of tasks such as fetching, organizing, or preparing, and skills such as opening or closing cabinets, drawers, appliances, and faucets in different homes.  The second and third objectives will be evaluated through user studies with both able-bodied and motor-impaired individuals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Robots that can assist humans in everyday tasks have the potential to improve people's quality of life and bring independence to persons with disabilities. A key challenge in realizing such robots is programming them to meet the unique and changing needs of users and to robustly function in their unique environments. Most research in robotics targets this challenge by attempting to develop universal or adaptive robotic capabilities. This approach has had limited success because it is extremely difficult to anticipate all possible scenarios and use-cases for general-purpose robots. Instead, this project aims to develop robots that can be programmed in-context and by end-users after they are deployed.

Towards this aim, our project sought to apply and extend methods from the broad research area of end-user programming, which has previously been limited to personal computers, smart phones, and web applications, to programming robots. This required addressing challenges related to distinct characteristics of robots including situatedness, ability to influence the environment, mobility, distributed concurrent processing, and overall complexity. The research conducted in this project resulted in two main outcomes:

(1) We developed novel interfaces, languages, and algorithms that enable robot users with different backgrounds to program new capabilities on robots. For example, we contributed a new method called situated tangible programming, where the user programs the robot simply by placing tangible markers, that can be robustly perceived by the robot, into the robot's workspace. We developed RoboFlow, a flow-based visual programming language that captures complex robotic tasks with an intuitive interface and allows program initialization through a single demonstration of the task. We developed algorithms that can iteratively improve social robot programs represented as Finite State Machines from simple corrections by the programmer, or implicit feedback from the user interacting with the robot. These and many more innovations from this project enable more intuitive and robust programming of robots.

(2) Through a large number of user studies with diverse users, we contributed new empirical knowledge about how people program robots. For example, across different programming languages and interfaces, we characterized differences between expert and novice programmers, which were often large in terms of efficiency of programming, but small in terms of the quality and generalizability of the programs. We demonstrated that people could use situated programming effectively, even without any instructions, purely based on the intuitive design of the tangible markers. We found that a simple addition to visual programming to handle concurrency, which is highly prevalent in robotics and difficult even for expert programmers, based on the idea of promises was intuitive even for novice programmers and resulted in more compact programs. These and many more findings from the studies conducted in this project inform the design of programming software that robotics companies develop for their robots given their task domains and users. 

Educational activities in the project focused on a project-based undergraduate class in which students programmed mobile manipulators to perform end-to-end assistive tasks. Outreach activities involved a summer program for high-school students with diverse disabilities where students prototyped robot applications. Both activities took advantage of the tools developed in this project while also providing additional evaluation of those tools and contributing new ideas for exploration or improvement.

As the robot programming tools developed in this project matured over the years, we turned our attention to our target user group of people with motor limitations. We developed new accessible interfaces for teleoperating assistive robots so they could be programmed by demonstration. In the final year of the project, we collaborated with an interdisciplinary team including an occupational therapist to deploy a robot in the home of a quadriplegic user. This final study demonstrated the great potential that accessible, programmable assistive robots have in enabling access to the physical world and increasing independence.

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2022
Modified by: Maya Cakmak
